awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Success of HBCUs Development of Blacks Earning Engineering and Computing Graduate Degrees
awd_abstract_narration:
Historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) have played a critical role in the production of African American and Black students in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). For graduate degrees, between 2002 and 2011, the National Science Foundation found that HBCUs comprised all ten of the top baccalaureate-origin institutions for Blacks who went on to obtain a doctorate degree in science and engineering. The predominance of HBCUs in the preparation of Black students for graduate programs suggests a need to better understand this under-explored success case and, in particular, the practices of these institutions that support prospective Black students as they explore and apply to graduate school. Identifying and disseminating these success cases will encourage HBCU and non-HBCU leaders to add resources towards matriculating more undergraduate students in STEM including increasing the number that go on to pursue masters and PhDs in engineering and computing. In addition, this study will provide an opportunity for non-HBCU organizations to better understand HBCUs, their culture and how they can be more strategic in partnering with them as well as recruiting and retaining engineering and computing HBCU students at the graduate level.  Through the resulting evidence-based insights and recommendations, this project will contribute to the goals outlined by the National Academies: (1) increasing underrepresented minority students' interest in graduate STEM degrees, (2) retaining and graduating Black students in those programs, and (3) documenting best practices for others to use.
Using a three-phased study, the research team will (1) examine the pathways and experiences of HBCU engineering and computing undergraduates who are interested in graduate school and (2) isolate the individual, institutional and cultural factors that contribute to their overall undergraduate experiences and lead to successful completion of engineering and computing graduate programs. Phase I will seek breadth by collecting survey data from current students and recent alumni associated with engineering and computing programs at HBCUs. Phase II will serve to develop rich insights from three particular HBCUs through in-depth, interview-based case studies. The three institutions will be selected through purposive sampling using maximum variation techniques of the Phase I results. Phase III will involve sharing the integrated results from Phases I and II with HBCU students and stakeholders during two validation workshops at the 2021 National Society of Black Engineers National Convention and at the 2021 Annual American Society for Engineering Education Annual Conference. The integrated results of these three phases will add to the research community's understanding of the experiences of Black students at HBCUs including the contribution of administrators, faculty and staff towards their students' interest, eventual pursuit and completion of engineering and computing graduate degrees. In addition, empirically-informed dissemination workshops will engage and equip stakeholders from HBCUs and other institutions to examine their own practices and adopt approaches that can increase underrepresented minority students' interest and preparedness for graduate programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview and Rationale

Historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs) have played a critical role in the production of African American and Black students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Between 2002 and 2011, the National Science Foundation (NSF) found that HBCUs comprised all ten of the top baccalaureate-origin institutions for Black students who went on to obtain a doctorate degree in science and engineering. The predominance of HBCUs in preparing Black students for graduate programs suggests a need to better understand this under-explored success case and the institutional practices that support this population as they explore and apply to graduate school. Identifying and disseminating these success cases will help education leaders and policymakers understand the importance and value of allocating more resources toward increasing the number of American undergraduate STEM students who pursue master’s and Ph.D. degrees in engineering, computing, and STEM more broadly. Additionally, this study provides an opportunity for the entire education community to better understand HBCUs, their culture, and how they can be more strategic in partnering with them and successfully recruiting and retaining HBCU students within graduate-level STEM programs. Through evidence-based insights and recommendations, this project will contribute to the goals outlined by the National Academies to increase historically excluded students obtaining graduate STEM degrees to meet U.S. STEM workforce demands and to conduct research to discover and document best practices in these spaces for broader implementation.

This research employs a three-phase study to examine the pathways of HBCU STEM students and the institutional and cultural factors that contribute to their success. Phase I involves survey data collection from students and alumni. Phase II uses in-depth interviews to explore key findings from the survey and obtain additional insights. The Phase III validation survey was completed by HBCU leaders and key stakeholders to review and connect Phase I and II results to their experiences, knowledge, and expertise. Through evidence-based insights and various dissemination pathways, this research study supports the entire higher education community in refining practices, ultimately broadening participation in STEM and strengthening the U.S. STEM workforce.

Intellectual Merit

Through the study’s three-phase approach and its mapping of both tangible and intangible resources that contribute to student success, the research goes beyond existing literature, which often only identifies available resources, by exploring how HBCUs provide and manage these support systems. The study highlights the layered approach HBCUs use to bridge undergraduate and graduate experiences, demonstrating how mentorship, faculty relationships, summer research opportunities, institutional resources, and professional development shape students’ academic trajectories, impact graduate school matriculation, and inform strategies for increasing participation among HBCU students in STEM and non-STEM graduate programs.

Additional analysis reveals a multifaceted support system that fosters academic excellence at the undergraduate level while empowering and encouraging students to pursue postgraduate studies (Table 1). As shown in Figure 1, conceptualizing these resources to illustrate how they are managed reveals a layered approach bridging the gap between undergraduate and postgraduate studies, addressing students’ evolving needs according to their pace of growth. This method facilitates personalized services and effective learning experiences, enabling seamless transitions for students. Additionally, the study explores how HBCUs’ student-centric and culturally driven approaches optimize resource allocation, particularly in the face of persistent underfunding. By contributing empirical evidence on best practices, this study enhances the broader understanding of participation in STEM by historically excluded individuals and informs strategies to improve student retention and graduate school transitions. Lastly, the Phase III validation survey, unlike traditional peer-review processes, served as a dynamic tool for engaging HBCU stakeholders about the merit and content of research. Results from this study produced two conference papers, four journal publications, and an additional publication under review at the time of this submission.

Broader Impacts

Beyond academic insights, this research has significant societal and institutional implications. Findings from the study provide actionable recommendations for HBCUs and non-HBCUs to enhance minority student participation in STEM graduate programs. By highlighting the importance of mentorship, faculty diversity, and financial support, the study can guide institutional policies and resource allocation to address challenges such as budget constraints, financial literacy, and campus infrastructure. Furthermore, the study underscores the importance of identity support for Black students in STEM, particularly in addressing barriers related to individual identifying factors.

In the Phase III validation survey, results showed strong faculty and administrative agreement on the key factors contributing to HBCU STEM students' academic success. Eighty-three percent of respondents strongly agreed or agreed that mentorship, faculty-student relationships, summer research opportunities, and professional development programs are critical for students’ interest and matriculation into STEM graduate degree programs. The study’s recommendations contribute to national discussions on broadening participation within the STEM workforce and fostering inclusive academic environments. By leveraging these insights, the project supports long-term systemic change in STEM education, ultimately broadening participation and success for HBCU students.


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Trina Fletcher

This approach addresses students� evolving needs at their own pace of growth, facilitating personalized services and fostering effective learning experiences.

    Layered Academic Support Conceptual Framework for HBCUs Resources
  • HBCUs support resources are divided into several key categories: foundational support, developmental opportunities, networking and community engagement, empowerment and confidence enhancement, and advanced support. Each of these major categories encompasses both tangible and intangible resources.
    Dr. Ahlam Alharbi and Dr. Trina Fletcher
    Copyrighted
    Trina Fletcher
    HBCU resources and success factors
